item.title: About Me
item.description:
Hello, my name is Anna Weichselbraun (/Ààva…™ÃØ√ß.s…ôl.b Åa äÃØn/), and I’m a linguistic and sociocultural anthropologist who studies relationships between knowledge, technology, and language.

My current research applies linguistic anthropology frameworks to large language models. In this introduction to a special issue in Journal of Linguistic Anthropology, Siri Lamoureaux, Michael Castelle, and I argue for the necessity of a linguistic anthropology of LLMs.

I co-coordinate the Language Machines Network, a monthly research forum bringing together scholars working at the intersection of language, technology, and society. Email languagemachinesnetwork@gmail.com to join the list!

item.title: Research
item.description:
Here are my current and ongoing research projects:

Photo: Generated by ideogram.io

AIdeology: Cultural Models of Language in Language Models

This project examines how cultural beliefs about language (language ideologies) shape the development, regulation, and social impact of Large Language Models (LLMs). Through ethnographic studies of EU regulation, compliance efforts, and local LLM development, the research aims to understand how AI technologies transform human communication and culture while developing methods that combine ML and linguistic anthropology.

item.title: Teaching
item.description:
Since 2018, I have taught in the Department of European Ethnology at the University of Vienna, where I offered courses on ethnographic method, language and meaning, infrastructures of trust, and the cultural politics of technology. My teaching is informed by ongoing research, and often involves experimentation with assignments, formats, and collaborative approaches to knowledge.

Language, Culture, and Semiotic Practice
Here I focus on how meaning is made in everyday life. Students learn to analyze linguistic and communicative practices using tools from linguistic anthropology and semiotics. We read classic and contemporary texts and explore how language ideologies shape institutions and technologies.
B420 Language and/as Culture (2021W)
B330 Ethnographic Perspectives on Language and Interaction (2020W)
M320 Cultural Practices and Semiosis in Everyday Life: Writing a Journal Article (2024S)
